{{Politics of the European Union}}
The '''European Civil Service''' is a generic term applied to all staff serving the [[Institutions of the European Union|institutions]] and [[Agencies of the European Union|agencies]] of the [[European Union]] (EU). Although recruitment is sometimes done jointly, each institution is responsible for its own internal structures and hierarchies.
==Principles of public service== The rules, principles, standards and working conditions of the European civil service are set out in the ''Staff Regulations''.<ref name="StaffRegs">{{cite web|url=https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A01962R0031-20140701|title=EUR-Lex - 01962R0031-20140701 - EN - EUR-Lex|author=|date=|website=europa.eu}}</ref>
The [[European Ombudsman]] has summarised the following five principles of public service which apply to all staff of the EU institutions:<ref name="Ombudsman">{{cite web|url=http://www.ombudsman.europa.eu/en/resources/publicserviceprinciples.faces|title=Public service principles for the EU civil service|first=European|last=Ombudsman|date=|website=www.ombudsman.europa.eu}}</ref>
:1. Commitment to the European Union and its citizens :2. Integrity :3. Objectivity :4. Respect for others :5. Transparency
==Staff== The European Commission's civil service is headed by a [[Secretary-General of the European Commission|Secretary General]], currently [[Martin Selmayr]] who succeeded Alexander Italianer in March 2018.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Eder|first1=Florian|title=Martin Selmayr secures Commission top job|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/martin-selmayr-secures-commission-top-job/|website=POLITICO|publisher=Politico|accessdate=10 March 2018|date=21 February 2018}}</ref> According to figures published by the Commission, 24,428 persons were employed by the Commission as officials and temporary agents in their 2016 budget.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.keele.ac.uk/pressreleases/2016/howmanypeopleworkfortheeu.html|title=How many people work for the EU?|last=Huggins|first=Christopher|date=2016-06-03|website=News and Events|publisher=Keele University|access-date=2016-09-04}}</ref> In addition to these, 9066 "external staff" were employed; these are largely people employed on time-limited contracts (called "contractual agents" in the jargon), staff seconded from national administrations (called "Detached National Experts"), or [[Traineeship scheme of the European Commission|trainees]] (called "stagiaires"). The single largest DG is the [[Directorate-General for Translation (European Commission)|Directorate-General for Translation]], with 2261 staff.<ref name="staff figures">{{cite web|title=Civil Service: Staff figures|publisher=[[Europa (web portal)]]|url=http://ec.europa.eu/civil_service/about/figures/index_en.htm |accessdate=2013-04-26}}</ref>
===Popular terminology=== European civil servants are sometimes referred to in the anglophone press as "[[Eurocrat]]s" (a term coined by [[Richard Mayne (journalist)|Richard Mayne]], a journalist and personal assistant to the first Commission president, [[Walter Hallstein]]).<ref name="Mayne">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2009/dec/21/richard-mayne-obituary|title=Richard Mayne obituary|date=22 December 2009|work=The Guardian|page=30|accessdate=22 December 2009 | location=London | first=Gillian | last=Tindall}}</ref> High-ranking officials are sometimes referred to as "European [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|Mandarins]]".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Life of a European Mandarin: Inside the Commission|last=Eppink|first=Derk-Jan|publisher=Lannoo|year=2007|isbn=978-9020970227|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref>.
These terms are sometimes erroneously used by the anglophone press, usually as a derogatory slur, to describe [[Member of the European Parliament|Members of the European Parliament]], or [[European Commissioner|European Commissioners]]. MEPs are directly elected representatives, whilst the European Commissioners, despite often being confused as civil servants, are politicians holding public office and accountable to the European Parliament. Much like [[government ministers]] at the national level, they instruct the policy direction of the civil service.
===Nationality=== There are staff from all member states, with the largest group being [[Belgium|Belgian]] (17.8% – 4,193), with [[France|French]] and [[Italy|Italian]] servants following with about 2,500 (10%).<ref name="staff figures"/>
Most administration is based in the [[Brussels|Belgian capital]],<ref name="staff figures"/> Often, those states under-represented in the service tend to have more of their nationals in the higher ranks.<ref>Eppink, 2007, p.35</ref>
===Qualifications=== {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2016}} The qualifications needed to enter the European civil service depend on whether the job is a specialist one and the grade.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nationalcareersservice.direct.gov.uk/advice/planning/jobprofiles/Pages/europeanunionofficial.aspx|title=Entry requirements|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Job profiles European Union official|publisher=UK Government Department for Business, Innovation and Skills|access-date=2016-09-04}}</ref> One of the entry qualifications for the European civil service is that the candidate speak at least two of the official European languages, one of which must be English, French or German. Candidates whose mother tongue is English, French or German must pass the competition for entry in one of the other two official languages.
Prior to their first promotion, officials must demonstrate competence in a third EU official language.
A candidate also needs to have a first degree in any discipline. The services have traditionally hired candidates with degrees in Law, Economics, or Audit; competition is tougher for graduates of all other disciplines, although the procedure for the open competitions, known as "Concours", is now under review.
===Grades=== Staff are divided into a set of grades: from AD 5, the most junior administrator grade, to AD 16, which is a director-general (AD = administrator). Alongside the AD category is AST (assistant). It is now possible for civil servants to be promoted from AST to AD grade, not previously possible (see below); however in practice the grades remain entrenched.<ref name="Eppink, 2007, p.37">Eppink, 2007, p.37</ref> While promotion is in theory according to merit, many management posts are now taken by officials 'parachuted in' from member states. Moreover, staff reforms introduced in 2004 have severely reduced the possibilities for career progression and have created divisions within the service, with pre-2004 entrants enjoying greater pay and privileges. According to the Commission's own internal statistics, even though new officials possess an average of eight years work experience, it would take an average of over 40 years to climb from AD 5 to AD 16.
Prior to this new system, introduced in the 2000s (decade), civil servants were traditionally divided into four categories. "A" was policy making (what is now AD), "B' was implementing, "C" was secretarial and "D" was drivers and messengers (B, C and D are now all part of the AST category). There were various grades in each category. The major ranks used to be in the form of A8 (new appointment without prior work experience) to A1 (director-general).<ref name="Eppink, 2007, p.37"/>
===Salary and allowances=== {{Citation needed span|date=January 2016|text=EU civil and other servants work 40 hours a week, though they are theoretically available 24/7. }} They receive a minimum of 24 days of leave a year (maximum of 30), {{Citation needed span|date=January 2016|text=with additional leave entitlements on grounds of age, grade but no longer distance from home country (this is now a flat-rate 2.5 days for all)}}.
The lowest grades receive between €1.618,83 gross (FG 1 step 1)<ref name="salary FG1">[http://ec.europa.eu/civil_service/docs/toc100_en.pdf Chapter 7, page II-30, Staff Regulation],</ref> each month, while the highest grades (AD 15–16 – i.e. Directors General at the end of their career) receives between €14,822.86 and €16,094.79 a month. This salary is taxed by the EU, rather than at the national level. Taxation varies between 8% and 45% depending on individual circumstances. This is paid into the [[Budget of the European Union|Community budget]].<ref name="salary">[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2004:124:0001:0118:EN:PDF COUNCIL REGULATION (EC, EURATOM) No 723/2004], Annex I, Amendment 60</ref>
Earnings are augmented by allowances, such as allowances for those living outside their own country, those who are the principal earner in their household, those with children in full-time education, and those who are moving home in order to take up a position or leaving the service. Earnings are also lowered by various additional taxes (i.e. "[https://webgate.ec.europa.eu/fpfis/mwikis/thinktank/index.php/Special_levy Special Levy]" alias 'crisis levy' introduced in 1973 and increasing regularly every year) and indexes (for EU staff working out-side Brussels).
For a contribution of 2% basic salary, employees are provided with health insurance which covers a maximum of 85% of expenses (100% for serious injury).<ref name="salary"/> Employees have the right to a parental leave of six months per person and child during which they obtain an allowance and have (as of January 2014) the possibility of an extension by further 6 months with a smaller allowance.<ref name="staff-reg-changes-2013">{{cite news|url=http://edz.bib.uni-mannheim.de/edz/pdf/swd/2013/swd-2013-0452-en.pdf|title=Summary document on changes relating to Staff Regulations review. Measures included in the compromise text agreed by COREPER on 28 June 2013 and voted in plenary session of the European Parliament on 2 July 2013. Ref. Ares(2013)2583641 – 05/07/2013|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=7 November 2014|format=PDF}}</ref>
{{Citation needed span|date=January 2016|text=Salaries were considerably reduced for new entrants from 1 May 2004 onwards as a result of a significant number of reforms effected by Commissioner Neil Kinnock. Staff undertaking the same work may receive very different salaries, depending on their date of recruitment. Careers are also sharply affected, with new staff tending to constitute a 'second division' of workers with limited managerial prospects. As a consequence of these changes, the institutions recruit with difficulty staff from certain countries like UK, Luxembourg, Denmark as wages are the same or lower than in the home country. For example, a Director General's salary is below what a senior executive with similar responsibilities could expect to be earning at the end of their career in the UK and in some countries (like Luxembourg) the lowest wages (FG I – FG II) are even under the legal [[minimum salary]] in the respective country, which raise the question about legality of such terms of employment.}}
In January 2010, The European Commission took the EU member states to court over the Member States' refusal to honour a long-standing formula under which wages for the staff of the European institutions are indexed to the salaries of national civil servants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anz.com/edna/dictionary.asp?action=content&content=wage_indexation|title=Glossary of terms - ANZ|author=|date=|website=www.anz.com}}</ref> The formula led to a salary adjustment of 3.7% but the Council, representing the member states, was only willing to grant a pay rise of 1.85%.<ref>http://www.euractiv.com/en/pa/eu-civil-servant-pay-row-goes-court/article-188646</ref> In November 2010, the European Court of Justice ruled that there was no legal basis for the Council to set the pay rise to 1.85%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.euractiv.com/pa/eu-officials-win-pay-rise-battle-news-499987|title=EU officials win pay rise battle with member states|date=26 November 2010|publisher=EuroActiv|accessdate=18 December 2014}}</ref> It has been noted that the ECJ judges who would decide in this case would be themselves to benefit from any salary increase agreed.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/eu/6942443/EU-mounts-challenge-to-MEP-pay-rise-cuts.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Bruno | last=Waterfield | title=EU mounts challenge to MEP pay rise cuts | date=2010-01-06}}</ref> To be noted that the index is published and applied one year and half later, and this delay cause the quarrels like in the 2010 (full crisis) where should be applied the adaptation related to the increases of wages of the national civil servants from 2007–8; while in 2011 the index was already negative (as the national wages has been lowered).
===Pensions=== Employees contribute about 11.3% of their basic salary to a pension scheme.<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:348:0009:0009:EN:PDF COUNCIL REGULATION (EU, EURATOM) No 1295/2009 of 22 December 2009 adjusting with effect from 1 July 2009 the rate of contribution to the pension scheme of officials and other servants of the European Union]</ref> This scheme does not constitute a separate, ring-fenced pension fund; rather, pension payments are made from the general administrative budget of the Commission.
Pensions are paid as a percentage of the final basic salary, with a ceiling of 70%, at an accrual rate of 1.8% per year of service<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/civil_service/job/official/index_en.htm|title=Permanent officials|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> (with a higher accrual rate of 1.9% per year of service for those who entered service between 1 May 2004 and 31 December 2013, and 2% per year of service for those who entered service before 1 May 2004<ref name="staff-reg-changes-2013"/>). The pensionable age is 66 years for staff entering service as of 1 January 2014, is between 63 and 65 years for those who entered service before 1 January 2014 but not earlier than 1 May 2004, and is between 60 and 65 years for those who entered service before 1 May 2004.<ref name="staff-reg-changes-2013"/> Early retirement is possible as of 58 years but a pension reduction coefficient of 3.5% is applied for each year before the pensionable age, except that for staff in place on 1 January 2014 the pension reduction coefficient is 1.75 for years not worked above the age of 60.<ref name="staff-reg-changes-2013"/>
Before 1 January 2014, the pensionable age had been 63 years for those who entered service on 1 May 2004 or later, and between 60 and 63 years for those who entered service before 1 May 2004. Early retirement was possible as of 55 years, albeit with a reduction of the pension due to the pension reduction coefficient of 3.5% per year before the pensionable age, except that a small percentage of officials could retire early without that pension reduction if it was in the interest of the service.<ref name="pensions_en_2012">{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/human-resources/pensions_en.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325101012/http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/human-resources/pensions_en.htm|title=Retirement pension and early retirement: Frequently asked questions|publisher=European Commission|date=6 January 2012|archive-date=25 March 2012}}</ref> To mitigate the changes implemented as of 2014, transitional pension rules were put in place for staff in place on 1 January 2014, which included setting the pensionable age for staff between 55 and 60 years of age on 1 January 2014 to lie between 60 and 61 years. Transition measures applied also to early retirement: Staff already aged 54 years or older on 1 January 2014 could still retire, with application of the pension reduction coefficient, in 2014 or 2015 at the age of 56 years or in 2016 at the age of 57 years.<ref name="staff-reg-changes-2013"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Irene Souka|url=http://www.u4unity.eu/document2/SR_HR20130712.pdf#page=12|title=Review of the Staff Regulations|date=July 2013|format=PDF|page=12}}</ref>
Before 1 May 2004, the pensionable age had been 60 years, and when this age was raised in 2004, this was accompanied by transition measures so that it remained unchangedly at 60 for officials aged 50 or more as well as for officials who had already completed 20 years of service or more on 1 May 2004, and it varied from 60 years and 2 months to 62 years and 8 months for officials aged 30 to 49 on 1 May 2004.<ref name="pensions_en_2012"/>
===Recruitment=== Recruitment is on the basis of competitions organised centrally by EPSO ([[European Personnel Selection Office]]) on the basis of qualifications and of the need for staff.
==Organisational culture== During the 1980s, the Commission was primarily dominated by French, German and Italian cultural influences, including a strictly hierarchical organisation. Commissioners and Directors-General were referred to by their title (in French) with greater prestige for those of higher ranks. As one former servant, [[Derk Jan Eppink]] has put it, even after new staff had passed the tough entrance exams: "Those at the top counted for everything. Those at the bottom counted for nothing."<ref>Eppink, 2007, p.32</ref> One example of this was the [[Chief of staff|chef de cabinet]] of [[President of the European Commission|President]] [[Jacques Delors]], [[Pascal Lamy]], who was particularly notable for his immense influence over other civil servants. He became known as the ''Beast of the [[Berlaymont building|Berlaymont]]'', the ''[[Gendarmerie|Gendarme]]'' and the ''[[Exocet]]'' due to his habit of ordering civil servants, even [[Directorate-General|Directors-General]] (head of departments) "precisely what to do – or else." He was seen as ruling Delors's office with a "rod of iron", with no-one able to bypass or manipulate him and those who tried being "banished to one of the less pleasant European postings".<ref>Eppink, 2007, p.22–3</ref>
However, since the enlargement of the EU, and therefore the arrival of staff from the many newer Member States, there has been a change in the culture of the civil service. New civil servants from northern and eastern states brought in new influences while the Commission's focus has shifted more to "participation" and "consultation". A more egalitarian culture took over, with Commissioners no longer having a "status equivalent to a sun God" and, with this new populism, the first women were appointed to the Commission in the 1990s and the service gained its first female secretary general in 2006 ([[Catherine Day]]). In stark contrast to the 1980s, it is not uncommon to see men without ties and children playing football in the corridors.<ref>Eppink, 2007, p.34–5</ref>
===Criticisms=== It has been alleged that, for want of a common administrative culture, European Civil Servants are held together by a "common mission" which gives DGs a particularly enthusiastic attitude to the production of draft legislation regardless of the intentions of the Commissioner.<ref>Eppink, 2007, p.111</ref> They are also notably bound by their common procedures, in the absence of a common administrative culture, which are best known by the [[Secretariat-General of the European Commission|Secretariat-General]], thus considered a prestigious office, just below the [[Cabinet (European Commission)|President's cabinet]].<ref>Eppink, 2007, p.218</ref>
There has been some criticism that the highly fragmented DG structure wastes a considerable amount of time in [[wikt:turf war|turf war]]s as the different departments and Commissioners compete with each other, as is the case in national administrations. Furthermore, the DGs can exercise considerable control over a Commissioner unless the Commissioner learns to assert control over his/her staff.<ref name="LEM">{{cite web|last=Amies|first=Nick|title = Former EU Mandarin Spills the Beans on Commission Intrigue|publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=2007-09-21|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,2790009,00.html|accessdate=2007-10-17}}</ref><ref name="Press Releases">{{cite web|last =Mahony|first=Honor|title=EU carefully manages PR through 1000s of press releases|publisher=EU Observer|date=2007-10-17|url=http://euobserver.com/9/24971|accessdate=2007-10-17}}</ref> The DGs work closely with the [[Cabinet (European Commission)|Commissioner's cabinet]]. While the DG has responsibility for preparation of work and documents, the cabinet has responsibility for giving the Commissioner political guidance. However, in practice both seek a share of each other's work.<ref>Eppink, 2007, p.109</ref> It has been alleged that some DGs try to influence decision making by providing Commissioners with briefing documents as late and large as possible, ensuring that the Commissioner has no time to do anything but accept the version of facts presented by the DG. In doing this the DG is competing with the cabinet, which acts as a "[[bodyguard]]" for the Commissioner.<ref>Eppink, 2007, p.107-8</ref>
==Organisational structure==
{{further|Directorate-General}} The Commission is divided into departments known as Directorates-General (DGs or ''the services''), each headed by a director-general, and various other services. Each covers a specific policy area or service such as External Relations or Translation and is under the responsibility of a [[European Commissioner]]. DGs prepare proposals for their Commissioners which can then be put forward for voting in the college of Commissioners.<ref name="Europa Institutions">{{cite web|title=Institutions of the EU: The European Commission|publisher=[[Europa (web portal)]]|url=http://europa.eu/institutions/inst/comm/index_en.htm|accessdate=2007-06-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070623104055/http://europa.eu/institutions/inst/comm/index_en.htm|archivedate=2007-06-23|df=}}</ref>
Whilst the Commission's DGs cover similar policy areas to the [[Ministry (government department)|ministries]] in national governments, European Civil Servants have not necessarily been trained, or worked, in a national civil service before employment in the EU. On entry, they do not therefore share a common administrative culture.

The '''''Federal Appendix''''' is a [[case law]] [[reporter (law)|reporter]] published by [[West Publishing]]. It publishes [[judicial opinion]]s of the [[United States courts of appeals]] that have not been expressly selected or designated for publication. Such "[[Non-publication|unpublished]]" cases are ostensibly without value as [[precedent]]. However, the Supreme Court made a change to the [[Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure]] in 2006. Now, Rule 32.1 says that federal circuit courts are not allowed to prohibit the citation of unpublished opinions issued on or after January 1, 2007.
Opinions of all the [[United States courts of appeals]] are included in the ''Federal Appendix''.<ref>{{official website|http://legalsolutions.thomsonreuters.com/law-products/Reporters/Federal-Appendix-National-Reporter-System/p/100000796}}</ref><!--this is the explanation from West's site, but why does this matter? is it because of the cost in procuring them by other means?--> "Published" opinions of the U.S. courts of appeals are published in the ''[[Federal Reporter]]''.
The ''Federal Appendix'' organizes court opinions within each volume by the date of the decision, and includes the full text of the court's opinion. West editors add headnotes that summarize key principles of law in the cases, and Key Numbers that classify the decisions by topic within the [[West American Digest System]].
However, unpublished opinions tend to be extremely concise and cryptic (especially when written by judges who are on record as disliking Rule 32.1), which limits their usefulness as precedent. They often avoid a full explanation of the facts and law (as is traditionally found in full-length appellate opinions) by reciting that such things are already known to the parties, which makes it difficult for anyone unfamiliar with the entire file for that particular case to discern the exact contours of the court's holdings in the opinion.
Over 700 hardbound volumes of the ''Federal Appendix'' have been issued since it began publication in 2001. Westlaw abbreviates citations to the Federal Appendix as '''Fed. Appx.''' The Bluebook calls for citations to the Federal Appendix to be abbreviated as '''F. App'x'''.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.legalbluebook.com/T-1-1|title=The Bluebook: A Uniform System of Citation|last=|first=|publisher=Harvard Law Review Association|others=Mary Miles Prince (Coordinating Editor)|year=2015|isbn=9780692400197|editor=Columbia Law Review Ass’n et al.|edition=20th|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=233|chapter=Table T1.1 Federal Judicial and Legislative Materials|oclc=986547050}}</ref>
There is debate within the legal community about the desirability of designating certain judicial opinions as without precedential value.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gant|first1=Scott E.|title=Missing the Forest for a Tree: Unpublished Opinions and New Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 32.1|journal=Boston College Law Review|date=2006|volume=47|page=705|url=http://lawdigitalcommons.bc.edu/bclr/vol47/iss4/2|accessdate=7 May 2017}}</ref>
==External links== *[http://legalsolutions.thomsonreuters.com/law-products/Reporters/Federal-Appendix-National-Reporter-System/p/100000796 Official West Publishing site for the ''Federal Appendix'']

{{italic title}} [[File:Madison FL 4 Freedoms mnmt08.jpg|thumb|200px|''Four Freedoms Monument'', [[Madison, Florida]]]] {{listen |title=State of the Union (Four Freedoms) (January 6, 1941) |filename=FDR's 1941 State of the Union (Four Freedoms speech) Edit 1.ogg |description =[[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]]'s January 6, 1941 [[State of the Union Address]] introducing the theme of the [[Four Freedoms]] (starting at 32:02) |image= }} The '''''Four Freedoms Monument''''' was commissioned by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] following his articulation of the "[[Four Freedoms]]" in his 1941 [[State of the Union Address]]. This was yet before the [[Attack on Pearl Harbor]] and the participation of the United States in [[World War II]]. Roosevelt felt that, through the medium of the arts, a far greater number of people could be inspired to appreciate the concept of the Four Freedoms.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.floridamemory.com/items/show/133035|title= Four Freedoms Monument - Madison, Florida |publisher = floridamemory |accessdate= October 1, 2016}}</ref>
According to Roosevelt, the four fundamental freedoms are: * [[Freedom of speech|Freedom of speech and expression]] * [[Freedom of worship]] * [[Freedom from want]] * [[Freedom from fear]]
The statue was created by [[sculptor]] [[Walter Russell]] later that year, and was dedicated in 1943 before a crowd of 60,000 people at [[Madison Square Garden]] in [[New York City]]. It was dedicated to [[Colin P. Kelly]], one of the first recognized American heroes of [[World War II]]. On June 14, 1944, the monument was re-dedicated in Kelly's hometown of [[Madison, Florida]], with a speech by Governor [[Spessard Holland]]. <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.museumoffloridahistory.com/exhibits/permanent/wwii/sites.cfm?PR_ID=58|title= Four Freedoms Monument|publisher = museumoffloridahistory|accessdate= October 1, 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Four Freedoms Monument, Evansville, Indiana.JPG|thumb|left|150 px|Four Freedoms Monument, Evansville, IN]] == Other related monuments == The Four Freedoms monument in [[Evansville, Indiana]] was designed by Evansville architect Rupert Condict. It consists of four 24-foot tall, ionic Indiana limestone columns, each with the inscription on it of one of the four freedoms. Surrounding these central columns are 50 uniformly shaped blocks representing the 50 states of the United States. Each block represents a state and shows its state seal and its date it became a state. The monument was dedicated in 1976 in commemoration of the [[United States Bicentennial]]. <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.celebrateevansville.com/four-freedoms/ |title= Four Freedoms Monument|publisher = celebrateevansville |accessdate= October 1, 2016}}</ref>
The Four Freedoms Monument of [[Cleveland, Ohio]] is located in the [[Tremont, Cleveland|Tremont]] neighborhood. It consists of a single column, with one of the four freedoms printed on each side. On top of the column is a sculpture of two hands holding a globe of the Earth.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://peace.maripo.com/p_four_freedoms.htm|title= Monuments (& Events) related to the "Four Freedoms" |publisher = peace.maripo |accessdate= October 1, 2016}}</ref>

'''General Order Number 38''' was issued by [[United States|American]] [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] general [[Ambrose Burnside]] on April 13, 1863, during the [[American Civil War]] while Burnside commanded the [[Department of the Ohio]]. Among other issues, the order attempted to make it illegal to criticize the war within that Department:{{cite book|author=George Henry Porter|title=Ohio Politics During the Civil War Period|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0npDAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA159|year=1911|publisher=Columbia UP|page=159}}
That hereafter all persons found within our lines who commit acts for the benefit of the enemies of our country, will be tried as spies or traitors, and, if convicted, will suffer death. This order includes the following classes of persons: ... The habit of declaring sympathies for the enemy will no longer be tolerated in the department. Persons committing such offences will be at once arrested, with a view to being tried as above stated, or sent beyond our lines into the lines of their friends.
Any kind of opposition to the war — such as that expressed by the [[Copperheads (politics)|Copperheads]] peace movement — was considered sympathy to the enemy, and the order was immediately used as justification to arrest Ohio Representative Vallandigham, a prominent leader in the movement (in fact, he was arrested for criticizing the order itself) and to try him in a military court. Burnside’s order inspired a political campaign song that mentioned [[Clement Vallandigham]]:
O, brothers, don't forget the time
When Burnside was our fate,
And laws were superseded
By order 38.
Then like a free-born western man,
Our Val spoke bold and true,
O, when he’s chosen governor
What will poor Burnside do.
Wont he skedaddle,
As he’s well used to do.p. 177, Porter, George Henry. Ohio Politics During the Civil War Period. NY, NY, 1911.

page.title: Gun control after the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/71.120.210.222|71.120.210.222]] ([[User talk:71.120.210.222|talk]]) to last version by Josvebot
revision.text:
After the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]], multiple [[Overview of gun laws by nation|gun laws]] were proposed in the United States at the federal and state levels. The shooting renewed debate about [[gun control]]. The debates focused on requiring [[National Instant Criminal Background Check System|background checks]] on all firearm sales (called universal background checks), and on passing new and expanded [[assault weapon]] and [[high-capacity magazine ban]]s.
==Background== On December 14, 2012, twenty children and seven adults were killed at [[Sandy Hook Elementary School]] in [[Newtown, Connecticut]].<ref name=Barron121215/> It was the deadliest primary or secondary [[school shooting]],<ref name=Effron121214/> the third-deadliest [[mass shooting]] by a single person,<ref name=Candiotti-Ford121216/> and one of the deadliest mass shootings in U.S. history.<ref name=CNNLib131026/>
==Initial response== {{Main|Reactions to the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting}} Within hours of the shooting, a [[We the People (petitioning system)|We the People]] user started a petition asking the [[White House]] to "immediately address the issue of gun control through the introduction of legislation in Congress,"<ref name=Bruce121214/><ref name=Wing121217/> and the gun control advocacy group the [[Brady Campaign|Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence]] reported that an avalanche of donations caused its website to crash.<ref name=New121214/> That afternoon, President [[Barack Obama]] made a televised statement offering condolences on behalf of the nation to Connecticut governor, [[Dannel Malloy]] and saying, "we're going to have to come together and take meaningful action to prevent more tragedies like this, regardless of the politics."<ref name=ObamaStmt121214/> Speaking at a December 16 memorial service in Newtown, Obama said he would "use whatever power this office holds" to prevent similar tragedies.<ref name=Landler-Baker121217/> By December 17, the White House petition had more than 150,000 signatures,<ref name=Wing121217/> and one week after the shooting it had almost 200,000, along with those on 30 similar petitions.<ref name=Levy121221/>
A ''[[USA Today]]''/[[Gallup (company)|Gallup]] poll conducted days after the shooting showed "mixed results" regarding public opinion on firearm laws.<ref name=Madhani121226/> While public support for strengthening gun laws rose 15 percent compared to a similar poll in 2011, there had been "little change in attitudes about some longstanding proposals, including the outlawing of assault rifles." A law requiring background checks for all gun-show sales was favored by 92 percent of Americans and a law banning the sale and possession of [[high-capacity magazine]]s (defined by the poll as those capable of holding more than 10 rounds) was supported by 62 percent of Americans. A record-high 74 percent opposed a ban on handguns and 51 percent opposed banning assault weapons.<ref name=Saad121227/>
==White House actions== On December 19, 2012, President Obama announced the formation of an inter-agency gun-violence task force headed by Vice President [[Joe Biden]].<ref name=ABCNews121219/> The task force held 22 meetings and collected ideas from 229 organizations.<ref name=Rucker-Wallsten130119/>
The [[National Rifle Association|NRA]] and congressional Republicans said that violent video games were a large part of the problem, but those did not end up on the final list of recommendations.<ref name=Rucker-Wallsten130119/> After meeting with Biden, the NRA issued a statement saying that it was "disappointed with how little this meeting had to do with keeping our children safe and how much it had to do with an agenda to attack the [[Second Amendment to the United States Constitution|Second Amendment]]."<ref name=Madhani130110/>
On January 16, 2013, President Obama announced a plan for reducing gun violence in four parts: closing background check loopholes; banning assault weapons and high-capacity magazines; making schools safer; and increasing access to mental health services.<ref name=WHNow-site/><ref name=WHNow-full/>{{rp|2}} The plan included 23 executive actions, signed immediately by the president, and 12 proposals for Congress.<ref name=MacAskill-Pilkington/>
The executive actions signed by President Obama were:<ref name=NYT-WHProposal130116/> * Issuing a presidential memorandum to require federal agencies to make relevant data available to the [[National Instant Criminal Background Check System]] (NICS). * Addressing unnecessary legal barriers, particularly relating to the [[Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act]] (HIPAA), that may prevent states from making information available to NICS. * Improving incentives for states to share information with NICS. * Directing the [[United States Attorney General|attorney general]] to review categories of individuals prohibited from having a gun to make sure dangerous people are not slipping through the cracks. * Proposing a rule making to give law enforcement authorities the ability to run a full background check on an individual before returning a seized gun. * Publishing a letter from the [[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives]] (ATF) to federally licensed gun dealers providing guidance on how to run background checks for private sellers. * Starting a national safe and responsible gun ownership campaign. * Reviewing safety standards for gun [[Trigger lock#Locks|locks]] and [[gun safe]]s ([[U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission|Consumer Product Safety Commission]]). * Issuing a presidential memorandum to require federal law enforcement to trace guns recovered in criminal investigations. * Releasing a report analyzing information on lost and stolen guns and making it widely available to law enforcement authorities. * Nominating an ATF director. * Providing law enforcement authorities, first responders and school officials with proper training for armed attacks situations. * Maximizing enforcement efforts to prevent [[gun violence]] and prosecute gun crime. * Issuing a presidential memorandum directing the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) to research gun violence. * Directing the attorney general to issue a report on the availability and most effective use of new gun safety technologies and challenging the private sector to develop innovative technologies. * Clarify that the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Affordable Care Act]] (ACA) does not prohibit doctors asking their patients about guns in their homes. * Releasing a letter to health care providers clarifying that no federal law prohibits them from reporting threats of violence to law enforcement authorities. * Providing incentives for schools to hire school resource officers. * Developing model emergency response plans for schools, houses of worship, and institutions of higher education. * Releasing a letter to state health officials clarifying the scope of mental health services that [[Medicaid]] plans must cover. * Finalizing regulations clarifying essential health benefits and parity requirements within insurance exchanges. * Committing to finalizing [[Mental Health Parity Act|mental health parity]] regulations. * Starting a national dialogue on mental health led by Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, and Arne Duncan, the secretary of education.
The White House's proposed congressional actions were these:<ref name=NYT-WHProposal130116/> * Requiring criminal background checks for all gun sales, including those by private sellers that currently are exempt. * Reinstating and strengthening the federal [[Federal Assault Weapons Ban|Assault Weapons Ban]] of 1994 (AWB 1994) that expired in 2004. * Limiting ammunition magazines to 10 rounds. * Banning the possession of armor-piercing bullets by anyone other than members of the military and law enforcement. * Increasing criminal penalties for [[Straw purchase|"straw purchasers"]] who pass the required background check to buy a gun on behalf of someone else. * Acting on a $4 billion administration proposal to help keep 15,000 police officers on the street. * Confirming President Obama's nominee for director of the (ATF). * Eliminating a restriction that requires the ATF to allow the importation of weapons that are more than 50 years old. * Financing programs to train more police officers, first responders and school officials on how to respond to active armed attacks. * Provide additional $20 million to help expand the system that tracks violent deaths across the nation from 18 states to 50 states. * Providing $30 million in grants to states to help schools develop emergency response plans. * Providing financing to expand mental health programs for young people.
The proposals were opposed by the NRA and the [[National Shooting Sports Foundation]] (NSSF),<ref name=Horwitz130116/> and opposition was expected by [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] and some [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] legislators.<ref name=MacAskill-Pilkington/><ref name=WSJ130116/>
==Advocacy groups actions== On December 21, 2012 - between the formation of Biden's task force and the announcement of Obama's proposals - [[Wayne LaPierre]], executive vice president of the [[National Rifle Association]] (NRA), expressed the gun-rights group's sympathy for the families of Newtown. LaPierre said that [[Gun-Free School Zones Act of 1990|gun-free school zones]] attract killers, and that "the media demonize lawful gun owners, amplify their cries for more laws, and fill the national media with misinformation and dishonest thinking that only delay meaningful action." He said, "The only thing that stops a bad guy with a gun is a good guy with a gun," and that debating legislation that won't work would be a waste of time. He called on Congress "to act immediately to appropriate whatever is necessary to put armed police officers in every single school in this nation" so that every school in America would be safe when pupils returned to school in January 2013. LaPierre announced that the NRA would develop a National Model School Shield Program for every American school that wants it.<ref name=LaPierre121221/>
After LaPierre's press conference, the Brady Campaign asked for donations to support its gun control advocacy and asked NRA members "who believe like we do, that we are better than this" to join its campaign.<ref name=ConnorIsikoff/> On January 8, 2013, former Congresswoman [[Gabrielle Giffords]], who was shot and injured in a [[2011 Tucson shooting|2011 shooting in Tucson]], launched [[Americans for Responsible Solutions]] to raise money for gun control efforts to counter the influence of powerful pro-gun groups such as the NRA.<ref name=BBC130108/>
==Congressional action==
===Proposed assault weapons ban=== {{Main|Assault Weapons Ban of 2013}} On January 24, 2013, Senator [[Dianne Feinstein]] and 24 Democratic cosponsors introduced {{USBill|113|S.|150}}, the Assault Weapons Ban of 2013 (AWB 2013).<ref name=CSPAN130124/><ref name=Freedman130124/> It was similar to the expired 1994 federal ban, but differed in that it used a one-feature test for a firearm to be considered an [[assault weapon]], rather than the two-feature test of the 1994 ban.<ref name=Kucinich130124/> Gun-control advocates said the stricter test would make the weapons less appealing to gun enthusiasts.<ref name=Freedman130124/> In addition, it would have banned: *the sale, transfer, importation or manufacture of about 150 named firearms; *firearms with "[[Stock (firearms)|thumbhole stock]]s" and "[[bullet button]]s"; *the importation of assault weapons and large-capacity magazines; *and large-capacity ammunition feeding devices (defined as those capable of holding more than 10 rounds).<ref name=Kucinich130124/> It would have grandfathered in weapons legally owned on the day of enactment and exempted 2,258 specific firearms "used for hunting or sporting purposes," of which only 33 were semiautomatic centerfire rifles.<ref name=Kucinich130124/><ref name=Chebium130124/>
Feinstein wanted the grandfathered firearms registered under the [[National Firearms Act]], which currently registers [[machinegun]]s, [[Suppressor|silencer]]s and [[short barreled shotgun]]s.<ref name=Summary121226/><ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k1iYl0coIOY</ref><ref>http://www.c-span.org/video/?310086-1/senators-feinstein-blumenthal-react-nra</ref>
On March 14, 2013, the [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|Senate Judiciary Committee]] approved the bill, though it was not expected to clear the full Senate or the [[United States House of Representatives|House]].<ref name=Steinhauer130314/><ref name=FoxNews130314/> Senate Majority Leader [[Harry Reid]] decided to leave the proposed ban out of the broader gun control bill, saying that it was unlikely to win 40 votes in the 100-member chamber and that it would jeopardize more widely supported proposals.<ref name=Simon130417/><ref name=Warren130417/> On the morning of April 17, 2013, the bill failed on a vote of 40 to 60. It was supported by Democrat Reid and Republican Senator [[Mark Kirk]], but 15 Democrats, one [[Independent (politician)|independent]], and all the Republicans except Kirk voted against the ban.<ref name=Simon130417/><ref>{{cite web|title=Senate Vote 101 - Rejects Feinstein Proposal to Reinstate Assault Weapons Ban|url=https://projects.propublica.org/represent/votes/113/senate/1/101|website=ProPublica|publisher=Pro Publica Inc.|accessdate=23 February 2018}}</ref>
===Proposed universal background checks=== The Manchin-Toomey Amendment was a bi-partisan piece of legislation sponsored by [[Joe Manchin]], a Democrat, and Republican Sen. [[Pat Toomey]] that would require background checks on most private party firearm sales.<ref name=LengellWashTimes04242013>{{cite news |title= Leaks hurt gun control bill, Sen. Pat Toomey says |author= Lengell, Sean |url= http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/apr/24/leaks-hurt-gun-control-bill-sen-pat-toomey-says/ |newspaper=''[[Washington Times]]'' |date= April 24, 2013 |accessdate=August 17, 2013}}</ref> The bill known as Manchin Amendment No. 715 was voted on and defeated on April 17, 2013 by a vote of 54 - 46. It needed 60 votes to pass.<ref name=KorteCamia130417>{{cite news |last1=Korte |first1=Gregory |last2=Camia |first2=Catalina |date=April 17, 2013 |title=Obama on Senate gun vote: 'A shameful day' |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2013/04/17/guns-background-checks-manchin-senate/2090105/ |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=April 17, 2013 }}</ref>
==State actions== {{See also|Gun laws in the United States by state|Assault weapons legislation in the United States#State assault weapon bans|l2=State assault weapon bans}} {{As of|2013|4|3|df=us}}, only five states had passed stricter gun control laws, while ten states had passed laws that weakened restrictions on firearms.<ref name=Hartmann130403/>
===Connecticut===
In the early morning hours of April 4, 2013, the [[Connecticut General Assembly]] passed new restrictions to the state's existing assault weapons ban. Governor [[Dannel Malloy]] signed them into law later the same day.<ref>{{cite news |date=April 4, 2013 |title=Connecticut Governor Signs Gun Measures |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/05/nyregion/connecticut-lawmakers-pass-gun-limits.html |newspaper=New York Times |location= |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=April 10, 2014 }}</ref> The law banned the sale or purchase of [[High-capacity magazine#Capacity|magazines capable of holding more than ten rounds of ammunition]] like those used in the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting, and required universal background checks for all firearm purchases.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mungin |first1=Lateef |last2=Brady |first2=Britanny |date=April 4, 2013 |title=Connecticut governor signs sweeping gun measure |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/04/04/us/connecticut-gun-law-overhaul/ |newspaper= |location= |publisher=Cable News Network |accessdate=April 10, 2014 }}</ref>
Gun owners challenged the law, but federal judge [[Alfred Covello]] upheld the law, ruling it constitutional and writing, "While the act burdens the plaintiffs' Second Amendment rights, it is substantially related to the important governmental interest of public safety and crime control." Gun owners said they would appeal.<ref>{{cite news |last=Pazniokas |first=Mark |date=January 30, 2014 |title=Federal judge upholds Sandy Hook gun law |url=http://ctmirror.org/federal-judge-upholds-sandy-hook-gun-law/ |newspaper=Connecticut Mirror |location= |publisher=Connecticut News Project |accessdate=April 10, 2014 }}</ref>
In February 2014, the ''[[Hartford Courant]]'' reported that Connecticut had processed about 50,000 assault weapons certificates, but that anywhere from 50,000 to 350,000 remained unregistered. "And that means," wrote the ''Courant's'' Dan Haar, "as of Jan. 1, Connecticut has very likely created tens of thousands of newly minted criminals — perhaps 100,000 people, almost certainly at least 20,000 — who have broken no other laws."<ref name=Haar140210/> [[Frank Miniter]] wrote in an April 2014 ''[[Forbes]]'' [[op-ed]] "that more than 300,000 Connecticut residents decided not to register their 'assault weapons,' moved them out of state, or sold them."<ref name=Miniter140413/>
===New York===
In January 2013, New York became the first U.S. state to act after the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. The Secure Ammunition and Firearms Enforcement (SAFE) Act passed in the state Senate 43-18 on January 15 and cleared the [[New York State Assembly]] after about five hours of debate on Tuesday, January 16. It was signed by Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]] one hour later. The act expanded the definition of assault weapons banned in New York, created a state database for pistol permits, reduced the maximum number of rounds legally allowed in magazines to seven from ten, and required universal background checks on all gun sales.<ref name=Seiler130116/>
A dozen Republican conference members voted for the measure, but its Senate Republican leader did not attend the signing ceremony.<ref name=Seiler130116/> The NRA called the assembly's actions "a secretive end run around the legislative and democratic process ... with no committee hearings and no public input," and said the law was "draconian."<ref name=Seiler130116/>
In a related move, the state comptroller announced that the state's pension fund would freeze its investments in publicly traded firearm manufacturers. The fund's holdings in [[Smith & Wesson]] had been sold in December, after the Connecticut shootings.<ref name=Seiler130116/>
Provisions of the SAFE Act have been challenged. On December 31, 2013, a federal court judge struck down the act's limit of seven rounds in magazines capable of holding 10, but upheld its expanded ban on assault weapons.<ref name=Spector131231/> As of April 2014 that decision was under appeal, and another challenge, that the bill was improperly fast-tracked, was dismissed by a trial-level judge. The plaintiff said that he will take that decision to the [[New York Court of Appeals]].<ref name=Klepper140416/>
Non-compliance with this new law has been reported in New York. [[Frank Miniter]] wrote in an April 2014 ''[[Forbes]]'' [[op-ed]] that one million residents own "assault weapons" and "high-capacity magazines" (which he says are political terms). He wrote that many had decided to practice civil disobedience and not register their weapons, a class A misdemeanor with a potential sentence of one year in prison.<ref name=Miniter140413/> ''USA Today'' reported that some owners threatened not to register their weapons, and that some chose to bypass registration by modifying or selling them before the April 15 deadline. State police say they cannot report how many people have registered. By law, they must keep their database of assault weapon owners private.<ref name=Campbell140413/>
===Maryland===
Late on April 4, 2013, the [[Maryland General Assembly]] passed Governor [[Martin O'Malley]]'s gun control bill, the Firearm Safety Act of 2013. It bans the purchase of 45 types of assault weapons and limits gun magazines to 10 rounds. It requires handgun licensing and fingerprinting for new gun owners, and bans those who have been involuntarily committed to a mental health facility from buying a gun.<ref name=Jackson130405/>

{{BLP sources|date=May 2011}}
'''Harold G. Maier''' is a noted scholar in the field of international law, international civil litigation, and conflict of laws. After receiving his undergraduate education at the [[University of Cincinnati]], he obtained his law degree from the [[University of Cincinnati College of Law]]. He also earned an LL.M. from the [[University of Michigan]]. He now holds the title of David Daniels Allen Professor of Law Emeritus at the [[Vanderbilt University Law School]].
In addition to being a prolific author, Maier has served as Counselor on International Law to the Legal Adviser at the [[U.S. Department of State]],<ref name="Ammann2009">{{cite book|last=Ammann|first=Daniel|title=[[The King of Oil: The Secret Lives of Marc Rich]]|date=2009-10-13|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-312-57074-3|pages=131–}}</ref> as a member of the [[U.S. Secretary of State]]'s Advisory Committee on [[Private International Law]], and as a consultant to the Office of the [[Secretary of the Army]] on the [[Panama Canal Treaty]] Negotiations. Additionally, he has testified before congressional committees on various issues, including emergency presidential controls on international economic transactions. In 1985 he was an expert witness for the U.S. Government in civil litigation resulting from the [[Mariel boatlift]].
At Vanderbilt, he established the law school's Transnational Studies Program as well as the [http://www.law.vanderbilt.edu/journal/ ''Vanderbilt Journal of Transnational Law''].

11 000 Beograd |budget = |website = [https://www.diplomacy.bg.ac.rs/index_en.php www.diplomacy.bg.ac.rs] |dissolved = |footnotes = }} The '''Institute of International Politics and Economics''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Институт за међународну политику и привреду}}) is a scientific institution established in 1947 and located in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]]. It is one of the oldest institutes in [[southeastern Europe]] and its scientist laid the foundations of [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] research of [[international relations]]. Over the years, the Institute has established close co-operation with the Serbian [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Serbia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]].{{cite journal | language = |title = Kosovo: Sui Generis or Precedent in International Relations | author = | pages = | publisher = Institute of International Politics and Economics | journal = | volume = | number = |date= | location = [[Belgrade]] | url = http://www.media.srbija.gov.rs/medsrp/dokumenti/agenda230318eng.pdf | accessdate = 15 September 2018 }} The Institute's associates have participated as experts in state and other delegations at the [[UN General Assembly]], the UN's Special Committees, the [[International Law Commission]], the [[International Law Association]], the [[United Nations Economic and Social Council]], [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade|GATT]], [[UNESCO]] and the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]]. The Institute's library holds over 150,000 titles and it is one of [[depository library|depository libraries]] for the [[United Nations]], [[European Union]] and [[NATO]], holding copies of each document and title published by the three [[international organisations]]. ==History== The Institute of International Politics and Economics was established on 7 December 1947 by a Decree of the [[Federal Executive Council (Yugoslavia)|Government]] of the [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia]] The decree was signed by [[Josip Broz Tito]], [[Andrija Hebrang (father)|Andrija Hebrang]], [[Milovan Đilas]], [[Aleksandar Ranković]] and [[Edvard Kardelj]]. The Institute is credited as one of the birthplaces of the idea for the establishment of the [[Non-Aligned Movement]]. Over the years, it has organised more than 500 national and international [[scientific conference]]s. In 2017 the Institute was awarded the Feast of the Presentation Order, [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Serbia|State decoration]] by the [[President of Serbia]], [[Tomislav Nikolić]].{{cite journal | language = |title = Укази о одликовањима које је потписао председник Републике Србије Томислав Николић | author = | pages = | publisher = [[President of Serbia|People´s Office of the President]] | journal = | volume = | number = |date= | location = [[Belgrade]] | url = https://www.predsednik.rs/predsednik/ukazi-o-odlikovanjima | accessdate = 15 September 2018 }} ==List of Directors== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! {{Abbr|No.|Number}} ! colspan=2 | Director{{cite journal | language = |title = History and Mission | author = | pages = | publisher = Institute of International Politics and Economics | journal = | volume = | number = |date= | location = [[Belgrade]] | url = https://www.diplomacy.bg.ac.rs/index_en.php | accessdate = 15 September 2018 }} ! colspan=2 | Term of office ! {{pp-protected|reason=Persistent addition of [[WP:INTREF|unsourced or poorly sourced content]]|small=yes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox website | name = KickassTorrents | logo = Kickasstorrentslogo.png | logo_size = 200px | logo_caption = | screenshot = | background = <!-- for collapsetext heading; default grey (gainsboro) --> | screenshot_size = <!-- default 300px --> | caption = | url = {{URL|https://katcr.co}} ([[#Revival|revival]]) | slogan = | commercial = <!-- "Yes", "No" or leave blank --> | type = Torrent [[Web directory|directory]], [[Magnet URI scheme|magnet links]] provider | registration = Optional | language = [[Multilingual]] (30+ languages, English primary language) | num_users = Over 1 million per day (August 2015) | content_license = <!-- or: | content_licence = --> | programming_language = | owner = | launch_date = {{start date and age|2008|11}} | revenue = | ip = | current_status = Offline | footnotes = }}{{File sharing sidebar}} '''KickassTorrents''' (commonly abbreviated '''KAT''') was a website that provided a [[web directory|directory]] for [[torrent file]]s and [[Magnet URI scheme|magnet links]] to facilitate [[peer-to-peer file sharing]] using the [[BitTorrent]] protocol. It was founded in 2008 and by November 2014, KAT became the most visited BitTorrent directory in the world, overtaking [[The Pirate Bay]], according to the site's [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]] ranking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alexa.com/topsites/global;3|title=Alexa Top 500 Global Sites|accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref> KAT went offline on 20 July 2016 when the domain was seized by the U.S. government. The site's [[proxy servers]] were shut down by its staff at the same time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/7/20/12243592/kickass-torrents-artem-vaulin-founder-arrested-domains-seized|title=KickassTorrents domains seized after alleged owner is arrested in Poland|accessdate=21 July 2016|date=20 July 2016|author=Nick Statt}}</ref>
In December 2016, former KAT staff members revived the KAT community by creating a website with its predecessor's features and appearance.<ref name="Revive" />
==Blocking and censorship== KickassTorrents says that it complies with the [[DMCA]] and it removes infringing torrents reported by content owners.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://kickass.to/dmca/|title=KAT DMCA|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225023020/http://kickass.to/dmca/|archivedate=25 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
KAT was initially launched in November 2008 at the [[domain name]] kickasstorrents.com.
On 21 April 2011, KickassTorrents moved to the [[Philippines]] domain name kat.ph after a series of domain name seizures by the [[United States Department of Justice]] against [[Demonoid]] and [[Torrentz]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Ernesto |url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-moves-to-kat-ph-110422/ |title=KickassTorrents Moves to Kat.ph |publisher=TorrentFreak |date=22 April 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> The site later moved to several different domains, which the operators plan to do every six months, including ka.tt, kickass.to, kickass.so, kickasstorrents.im and kat.cr.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-moves-to-isle-of-man-domain-name-150423|title=KickassTorrents Moves to Isle of Man Domain Name|publisher=TorrentFreak|accessdate=23 April 2015|date=23 April 2015|author=Ernesto}}</ref>
On 28 February 2013, [[Internet service provider]]s (ISPs) in the [[United Kingdom]] were ordered by the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] in London to block access to KickassTorrents, along with two other torrent sites. Judge [[Richard Arnold (judge)|Richard Arnold]] ruled that the site's design contributed to [[copyright infringement]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/feb/28/online-piracy-isps-block-access |title=Online piracy: ISPs ordered to block access to three file-sharing websites|work=The Guardian |accessdate=1 March 2013|location=London|first=Lisa|last=O'Carroll|date=28 February 2013}}</ref><ref name = "bailii_2013">{{cite BAILII |litigants=EMI Records Limited, Infectious Limited, Liberation Music Pty Limited, Polydor Limited, Simco Limited, Sony Music Entertainment UK Limited, Universal Music Operations Limited, Virgin Records Limited, Warner Music UK Limited, Weainternational Inc v British Sky Broadcasting Limited, British Telecommunications Plc, Everything Everywhere Limited, TalktalkTelecom Group Plc, Telefónica UK Limited, Virgin Media Limited|court= EWHC |division=Ch |year=2013 |num=379 |date=28 February 2013|courtname=auto |juris=England and Wales}}</ref>
On 14 June 2013, the domain name was changed to [[Tonga]] domain name kickass.to as a part of the site's regular domain change.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://kickass.to/blog/post/36016/ |title=Moving to Kickass.To — Blog — KickassTorrents |publisher=Kickass.to |accessdate=15 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140314220809/http://kickass.to/blog/post/36016/ |archivedate=14 March 2014 |df= }}</ref>
On 23 June 2013, KAT was delisted from [[Google Search|Google]] at the [[MPAA#Anti-piracy efforts|request of the MPAA]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/mpaa-kicks-kickasstorrents-off-google-with-precision-takedown-130623/ |title=MPAA Kicks KickassTorrents Off Google With ‘Precision’ Takedown|publisher=TorrentFreak |accessdate=24 June 2013|date=23 June 2013|author=Ernesto}}</ref> In late August 2013, KAT was blocked by [[Belgium|Belgian]] ISPs.<ref>{{cite web | title = Belgische providers blokkeren meer torrentsites | url = http://tweakers.net/nieuws/90965/belgische-providers-blokkeren-meer-torrentsites.html | language = Dutch}}</ref> In January 2014, several [[Ireland|Irish]] ISPs started blocking KAT.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://torrentfreak.com/irish-internet-providers-roll-out-kickasstorrents-blockade-140119/ |title=Irish Internet Providers Roll Out KickassTorrents Blockade |date=19 January 2014 |publisher=TorrentFreak |accessdate=19 January 2014}}</ref> In February 2014, [[Twitter]] started blocking links to KAT, however by the end of February 2014, KAT was unblocked on Twitter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/twitter-blocks-kickass-links-says-theyre-unsafe-140221/ |title=Twitter Blocks Kickass.to Links, Says They're Unsafe |publisher=TorrentFreak |accessdate=25 February 2014|date=21 February 2014}}</ref> In June 2014, KAT was blocked in [[Malaysia]] by the [[Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission]] for violating copyright law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.funnymalaysia.net/kickass-to-has-been-officially-blocked-in-malaysia/|title=Kickass.to has been officially blocked in Malaysia|date=25 June 2014|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref>
In December 2014, the site moved to the [[Somalia]] domain name kickass.so. Reports stated that it was moved as a result of site's regular domain change.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/KickassTorrent-Moves-Domain-to-Somalia-465257.shtml|title=KickassTorrent Moves Domain to Somalia|publisher=Softpedia News|accessdate=21 July 2016|date=18 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-moves-kickass-so-domain-name-141117/|title=KickassTorrents Moves to Kickass.so Domain Name|publisher=TorrentFreak|accessdate=21 July 2016|date=17 November 2015}}</ref> On 9 February 2015, kickass.so was listed as "banned" on [[Whois]], causing the site to go offline. Later that day, the site reverted to its former domain name kickass.to.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-taken-domain-name-seizure-150209/|title=Kickass Torrents taken down by domain name seizure|author=Ernesto|publisher=TorrentFreak|date = 9 February 2015|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref>
On 14 February 2015, it was found that messages mentioning "kickass.to" were blocked on [[Steam (software)|Steam]] chat, but "kickass.so" and other popular torrent websites were not blocked, only flagged as "potentially malicious".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/steam-censors-kickass-mentions-chat-client-150214/|title=Steam Censors Kickass.to Mentions in Chat Client|author=Ernesto|publisher=TorrentFreak|date = 14 February 2015|accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref>
On 23 April 2015, the site moved to the [[Isle of Man]] based domain name kickasstorrents.im<ref>{{cite web|url = https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-moves-to-isle-of-man-domain-name-150423/|title = KickassTorrents Moves to Isle of Man Domain Name|date=23 April 2015|accessdate = 7 June 2015}}</ref> but was quickly taken down later that day and on 24 April it was moved to the [[Costa Rica]] based domain name kat.cr.<ref>{{cite web |title=KickassTorrents is moving to kat.cr domain |url=https://kat.cr/blog/post/kickasstorrents-is-moving-to-kat-cr-domain |website=kat.cr |date=25 April 2015 |accessdate=7 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150606110328/http://kat.cr/blog/post/kickasstorrents-is-moving-to-kat-cr-domain/ |archivedate= 6 June 2015 |df= }}</ref>
By July 2015, the kat.cr address had been removed from [[Google Search]]'s results. After the removal, the top Google search result for KAT in many locations pointed to a fake KAT site that prompted visitors to download [[malware]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-disappears-from-google-after-penalty-150718/|title=KickassTorrents Disappears From Google After Penalty|publisher=TorrentFreak|accessdate=20 July 2015|date=18 July 2015|author=Ernesto}}</ref>
In October 2015, [[Portugal]] bypassed its courts by making a voluntary agreement between ISPs, rightsholders and the Ministry of Culture to block access to KAT and most of the other popular BitTorrent websites.<ref>{{cite web|title = Portugal Blocks Popular Torrent and Streaming Sites| publisher=TorrentFreak|url = https://torrentfreak.com/portugal-blocks-popular-torrent-and-streaming-sites-151026/|accessdate = 21 July 2016|date=26 October 2015|author=Ernesto}}</ref>
At the same time, [[Google Chrome]] and [[Mozilla Firefox]] blocked access to KAT because of security concerns with some of the ads pointing to malware.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-blocked-again-over-harmful-programs-151021/|title=KickassTorrents Blocked Again Over "Harmful Programs"|date=27 October 2015|accessdate=21 July 2016|author=Ernesto}}</ref> In April 2016, Google Chrome and Mozilla Firefox blocked KAT due to [[phishing]] concerns.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chrome and Firefox Block KickassTorrents as "Phishing" Site|url=https://torrentfreak.com/chrome-and-firefox-block-kickasstorrents-as-phishing-site-160412/|accessdate=12 April 2016|work=TorrentFreak|date=12 April 2016}}</ref> Both blocks were later removed after KAT dealt with the concerns.
In June 2016, KAT added an official [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]] network .onion address.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-enters-the-dark-web-adds-official-tor-address-160607/|title=KickassTorrents enters the dark webs, adds official Tor address|publisher=Torrentfreak|date=7 June 2016|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref>
One of the main domains of the site went up for sale in August 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thetechverse.com/kickasstorrents-domain-sale/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810014110/https://www.thetechverse.com/kickasstorrents-domain-sale/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 August 2016|title=KickassTorrents Domain for Sale at just $230|accessdate=9 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fossbytes.com/kickasstorrents-main-domains-kat-cr-kickass-cr-sale/|title=KickassTorrents Domain Goes Up For Sale For A Minimum Bid of $230|accessdate=9 August 2016}}</ref>
==Arrest of the alleged owner== [[File:KickassTorrents Domain seizure.jpg|thumb|Notice displayed on KickassTorrents sites after its seizure.]] On 20 July 2016, the [[United States Department of Justice]] announced that it had seized the KAT.cr domain and had identified its alleged owner. Artem Vaulin ({{Lang-uk|Артем Ваулін}}), a 30-year-old [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] man known online as "tirm", was detained in Poland after being charged with a four-count U.S. criminal indictment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/jul/20/kickass-torrents-targeted-doj-feds-say-website-dis/|title=Kickass Torrents targeted by DOJ, feds say website distributed $1 billion in copyrighted works|work=[[Washington Times]]|date=20 July 2016|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> The remaining domains were taken offline voluntarily after the KAT.cr domain name was seized.<ref name="torrentfreak-kat-feds">{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/feds-seize-kickasstorrents-domains-charge-owner-160720/|title=Feds Seize KickassTorrents Domains, Arrest Owner|work=[[TorrentFreak]]|last=Van der Sar|first=Ernesto|date=20 July 2016|access-date=21 July 2016|quote=At the time of writing the main domain name Kat.cr has trouble loading, but various proxies still appear to work. KAT’s [https://kastatus.com/ status page] doesn’t list any issues, but this will be updated shortly.}}</ref> Following the seizure of the original KAT domain multiple unofficial mirrors have been put online. These have no connection to the original team who have been urging users to exercise caution.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Van Der Sar|first1=Ernesto|title=KickassTorrents Mirrors and Imposters Spring into Action|url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-mirrors-and-imposters-spring-into-action-160722/|website=Torrent Freak|accessdate=2 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Van der Sar|first1=Ernesto|title=KickassTorrents Community Resurrects, Without Torrents|url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-community-resurrects-without-torrents-160725/|website=Torrent Freak|accessdate=2 August 2016}}</ref> A number of these mirrors have since been taken down.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Protalinski|first1=Emil|title=KickassTorrents mirrors go down, but new KAT sites quickly spring up|url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/07/31/kickasstorrents-mirrors-go-down-but-new-kat-sites-quickly-spring-up/|website=Vebture Beat|publisher=VentureBeat|accessdate=2 August 2016}}</ref>
Vaulin was arrested after investigators cross-referenced an [[IP address]] he used for an [[iTunes]] transaction with an IP address used to log into KAT's [[Facebook]] page. The [[FBI]] also posed as an advertiser and obtained details of a bank account associated with the site.<ref name="torrentfreak-kat-feds"/> The investigation was led by special agent Jared Der-Yeghiayan, who also tracked down [[Ross Ulbricht]], the operator of the online black market [[Silk Road (marketplace)|Silk Road]].<ref name="investigation">{{cite web|url=http://mobile.abc.net.au/news/2016-07-21/how-the-us-government-brought-down-kickass-torrents/7649862|title=Kickass Torrents: How did the US Government bring down the file-sharing site?|work=news.com.au|last=Ockenden|first=Will|date=22 July 2016|access-date=24 July 2016}}</ref>
The criminal complaint, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois]] by [[Homeland Security Investigations]], said that it was in possession of full copies of KAT's hard drives, including its [[Message transfer agent|email server]]. The investigation suggested that KAT made over $12 million per year in advertising revenue.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/can-kickasstorrents-make-a-comeback-160721/|title=Can KickassTorrents Make a Comeback?|work=TorrentFreak|date=21 July 2016|access-date=21 July 2016}}</ref>
In late August 2016, the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] followed the complaint with a full [[grand jury]] [[indictment]] of Vaulin and two other defendants, Ievgen Kutsenko and Oleksandr Radostin; while Vaulin was still being held in Polish prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/u-s-government-indicts-three-alleged-kickasstorrents-operators160825/ |title=U.S. Government Indicts Three Alleged KickassTorrents Operators|last=Van der Sar|first=Ernesto |work=TorrentFreak|date=25 August 2016|accessdate=25 August 2016}}</ref> Vaulin has both a Polish and US legal representation [[Ira P. Rothken|Ira Rothken]] as his lawyers to handle the allegations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-alleged-owner-retains-kim-dotcoms-lawyer-160728/ |title=KickassTorrents’ Alleged Owner Retains Kim Dotcom’s Lawyer|last=Van der Sar|first=Ernesto |work=TorrentFreak|date=28 July 2016|accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.completemusicupdate.com/article/extradition-proceedings-underway-in-kickass-case/ |title=Extradition proceedings underway in Kickass case |publisher=Complete Music Update |date=2016-10-04 |accessdate=2016-10-09}}</ref> In November 2016, a Polish appeals court refused to allow [[bail]] for Vaulin, stating the evidence provided by the US is sufficient to keep him in prison.<ref>[https://torrentfreak.com/alleged-kickasstorrents-owner-stays-in-prison-court-rules-161002/ Alleged KickassTorrents Owner Stays in Prison, Court Rules] November 2, 2016</ref>
==Revival== In mid-December 2016, some of the former KAT staff and moderators launched a website with a similar appearance as the original under the domain katcr.co.<ref name="Revive">{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/kickasstorrents-brought-back-to-life-by-original-staffers-161216/|title=KickassTorrents Brought Back to Life by Original Staffers (Updated) - TorrentFreak|date=16 December 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
